author: Cixin Liu
title: Death's End
summary: Last of the Three-Body Series.  Progressed pretty slowly for me, partly retelling previous events from a different point of view, but the end more than made up for it.  The final view of the universe Liu paints at the end had my mind spinning for days.

author: Cixin Liu
title: The Dark Forest
summary: Sophomore album.  Good in it's own right.  Great in the context of the trilogy.

author: Cixin Liu
title: The Three-Body Problem
summary: It's hard to evaluate each of the three books in the series on its own.  This had a bit of a slow start, but really drew me in after.  I read all three so quickly I forget exactly where one left off and the next started.  I'm not normally much a reader of science fiction, but this trilogy is highly recommended.

author: James Watson
title: The Double Helix
summary: Story of the discovering of the DNA helix from one of it's founders.  Got a few chapters in, but didn't really grab me.

author: Edvard Radzinsky
title: Stalin
summary: Biography of one of the most ruthless and effective dictators ever.  Stalin inherited a rural peasantry and transformed it into an industrial superpower in 20 years, while waging war against Hitler, taking some 50 million lives in the process.

author: Jack Weatherford
title: Genghis Khan and the Making of the Modern World
summary: The life of Tem'_jin and how the values the Mongols carried with the as they built their empire laid the foundation for much of what we consider the hallmarks of modernity.

author: Yuval Noah Harari
title: Homo Deus
summary: Loved this book.  So much to say about how the next hundred years of technological development will fundamentally change what it means to be human.

author: Tyler Cowen
title: The Complacent Class
summary: Prediction of the increasing tendancy for Americans to keep the country the way it is.  It didn't grab me as much as his previous two, and didn't pick it up after the flight I started it on.

author: Twyla Tharp
title: The Creative Habit
summary: I've been trying to restart a creative thinking habit.  Picked the book up, put it down, then did so again.  I feel I got a better return on investment from The Artist's Way.

author: Walter Isaacson
title: The Innovators
summary: The 150 year history of the hundreds of inventors and contributors that gave rise to personal computers, the Internet and the modern information age.  Similar in spirit to The Making of the Atomic Bomb in all the best ways possible.

author: John Miles White
title: Bandit Algorithms for Website Optimization
summary: Basic coverage on the motivation and techniques for using multi-arm bandit algorithms to continually tweak websites.

author: Ben Rich
title: Skunkworks
summary: History and accomplishments of Lockheed's special projects group responsible for the U2, the SR-71 and the stealth fighter amongst other aircraft.  A study in small teams doing amazingly innovative work.

author: Vasily Grossman
title: A Writer at War
summary: Notes from one of the most widely traveled World War II Soviet reporters.  Grossman had nearly-unrestricted access to the Soviet Eastern Front and he paints a very comprehensive picture of life on the ground.  Chilling, to say the least.

author: Dave Asprey
title: Head Strong
summary: Tour of many approaches to improve cognitive function.  I do some already and will need to test the rest before reporting back on efficacy.

author: Richard Rhodes
title: Dark Sun
summary: Followup to the excellent Making of the Atomic Bomb.  Expands coverage to include Russian scientific/technical developments and espionage.  Somehow it didn't grab me as much and I put it down half way through.

author: Massimo Pigliucci
title: How to Be a Stoic
summary: Another book on Stoic philosophy.  A few good explanations, but mostly a rehash for me.  However, I think it's worth it for the practical spirtual exercises alone, which echo [Ben Franklin's virtues](http://www.thirteenvirtues.com/).

author: Tom Wolfe
title: The Right Stuff
summary: History of the Mercury 7 program and the first astronauts.  Rocket planes, fighter-jock machismo and the willingness to place oneself in the path of danger to prove you have it.  I really enjoyed this.

author: Cameron Davidson-Pilon
title: Bayesian Methods for Hackers
summary: Started it and immediately switched to [Doing Bayesian Data Analysis](http://amzn.to/2ofEY0g) for more depth.  I find this book best as a tutorial for [PyMC3](https://pymc-devs.github.io/pymc3/).

author: James Gliek
title: Genius: The Life and Science of Richard Feynman
summary: Doesn't play up his persona as much as [Surely You're Joking](http://amzn.to/2qNdbZN) but covers the history and implications of his physics well.  I didn't find a whole lot new in it, but I've already read most other books on Feynman and his area.

author: Chris Bellamy
title: Absolute War
summary: First in what I imagine will be many books about the Eastern Front of WWII.  I highly recommend Dan Carlin's [Ghosts of the Ostfront](http://www.dancarlin.com/product/hardcore-history-ghosts-ostfront-series/) series, if you're at all curious. The book focused on military operations and the logistics of those movements, and vignettes of the major characters.  While I didn't want the book to be overwhelmed with stories from the front, I found the book glossed over it to a surprising degree.  If you skim too fast, you could miss a million deaths.

author: Kim Zetter
title: Countdown to Zero Day
summary: The story behind Stuxnet, sabotage of the Iranian nuclear program and the vulnerability of infrastructure in the coming age of cyber-warfare.  The future is scary.

author: Daniel Coyle
title: The Talent Code
summary: What is necessary to give rise to talent, in any area.  I'm having trouble summarizing it, but there are some good gems among the pop-neuroscience and personal anecdotes.

author: William Manchester
title: The Last Lion: Winston Spencer Churchill: Defender of the Realm, 1940-1965
summary: Continuing the previous biography about Churchill's time as Prime Minister during WWII.  I got too fascinated in the Eastern Front and stopped in favor of reading on that.

author: Timothy C. Urdan
title: Statistics in Plain English
summary: This is the intro frequentist statistics book I've been looking for.  There's dozens of books that cover the basic curriculum, but the majority either assume move too slowly for me or assume too much background.  This one hit the sweet spot.

author: William Manchester
title: The Last Lion: Winston Spencer Churchill: Alone, 1932-1940
summary: 2nd in a Winston Churchill biography trilogy.  My main takeaway was a greater understanding of the run-up to WWII.

author: Oliver Sacks
title: Gratitude
summary: Oliver Sacks looks back on his life and contemplates old age.  A short, endearing reminder of where one's priorities should be.  This one will be reread many times.

author: David Diez, Christopher Barr & Mine Oetinkaya-Rundel
title: OpenIntro Statistics
summary: Intro stats book.  Moved too slowly, and hand-waved away too many details for me.  If you want to understand this subject matter, I recommend [Statistics in Plain English](http://amzn.to/2oztSqn) instead.

author: Frank Herbert
title: Dune
summary: Never fear, I've read it before; I'll read it again.  The hardcover edition was too good to pass up.

author: Adam Steltzner
title: The Right Kind of Crazy
summary: Book on curiosity and technical leadership (that is leading both technological development and the people doing it) by the JPL scientist responsible for the _Curiosity_ Sky Crane.

author: Edward Hallowell
title: Driven to Distraction
summary: Definitive work on ADHD, especially in adults.  While most pertinent to those with ADHD, I think it's lessons broadly applicable.  On any topic, the best instruction often comes from the ones for which a skill comes the least naturally.  The systems and psychology that help the distractable get stuff done are of interest to all.

author: Paul Kalanithi
title: When Breath Becomes Air
summary: The words of the dying are perhaps the best advice on how to live.

author: Norman MacRae
title: John Von Neumann
summary: Father of the modern computer, among many other accomplishments.  While an innate genius (a term much overused, but truly warranted here) his skill was as much nuture as nature.  As such, the book provides nuggets to develop your own thinking skills.

author: Elizabeth Dunn & Michael Norton
title: Happy Money
summary: Survey of scientific literature regarding how money affects our emotional well-being.  Sadly, some of the examples confuse correlation and causation, but the overall advice is very useful to consider if you want to buy the most happiness for your dollar.

author: Benjamin Todd
title: 80,000 Hours
summary: A well-reasoned examination of how to do the most social good with one's career, focused on readers just starting theirs.

author: Neal Stephenson
title: Seveneves
summary: After writing Anathem, Neal asked himself "what if instead of 90% plot and 10% orbital mechanics, the next book was the other way around?"  Snark aside, I loved this, especially the first 2 acts.

author: Neal Stephenson
title: Anathem
summary: If academia decided to really double-down on the ivory town.

author: Gordon Livingston
title: Too Soon Old, Too Late Smart
summary: 30 statements about making sense of mortality, relationships and modern life.  Some of the points hit so deeply it was physically uncomfortable to read at times.  This is one of those books you reread portions of every few months until the work their way into your being.  Recommended.

author: Daniel Yergin
title: The Quest
summary: Tackling the massive topic of global energy, politics, national security and the course of events that got us to the modern day.  Mostly told through small vignettes to illustrate particular points, this grabbed me much more than expected.

author: Eric Greitens
title: Resilience
summary: Lessons on cultivating resiliance from a Navy Seal.  I made it through the first 100 pagse but it feels like a book to be digested in small chapters over time.

author: Yuval Harari
title: Sapiens
summary: A Big History book ala Guns, Germs and Steel.  Interesting points but, similar to GG&S, the scope is so broad I found it difficult to overcome my skepticism that the author is only picking from the surface to support their chosen narrative. I read the first half and only skimmed the latter.  I may just not like the genre.

author: Jean Edward Smith
title: FDR
summary: Detailed biography of of the third great President, along with Washington and Lincoln.  I had not appreciated how much the current scope of the executive branch and the involvement of the US government in well-being of all Americans was a result of his terms.  See also PBS's exellent series [The Roosevelts](http://www.pbs.org/kenburns/the-roosevelts).

author: Arnold Bennett
title: How to Live on 24 Hours a Day
summary: A short essay on how not to waste your life.  If Seneca's _On the Shortness of Life_ is the strategy, this is one set of simple tactics.

author: Charles Mann
summary: The New World as it actually was.  Contrary to what is taught in school, Columbus did not land in a sparsely settled, near-pristine wilderness and instead encountered a continent populated by advanced civilizations.

author: John Vaillant
title: The Tiger
summary: Tiger in Russia turns man-eater.  Combo special ops/animal warden team hunts tiger.  Tiger hunts them.  Insanity that is Russia.  Man vs. alpha preditor.

author: Tim Ferriss
title: Tools of Titans
summary: Agree or disagrees Ferriss' priorities, he's excellent at distilling things down into actionable life-hacks.  This is his most wide-reaching book yet.  Lots of things to apply to your life.

author: Ryan Avent
title: The Wealth of Humans
summary: How does technological progress alter the relationship of Labor and Capital.  What does the future look like when there isn't enough work for the members of society?  I can't tell whether the book was superficial or I simply didn't understand it.

author: Daron Acemoglu & James Robinson
title: Why Nations Fail
summary: Extractive political and economic institutions that maintain advantage for the minority elite are largely responsible for why nations fail to develop economically.

author: Steward Brand
title: How Buildings Learn
summary: Got distracted half way through, but still got a lot out of it.  I've always considered architecture and software development to have interesting parallels and this reinforced that idea.  Biggest insight: certain buildings being like blue jeans where they improve with use and wear.  Many things that interest me share that concept.

author: Mortimer Adler & Charles Van Doren
title: How to Read a Book
summary: How-to guide for reading books.  While seemingly obvious, most of us were not taught the skills necessary for digesting difficult reading material.  This book presents a 4-level approach for understanding great books.  Ironically, I didn't finish it.

author: Christian Rudder
title: Dataclysm
summary: A study of how of human behavior on social networks.  How do people think and act towards their fellow members of society when no ones looking.  Many of the problems that came to light in 2016 have been around for a long time.

author: Reid Hoffman
title: The Alliance
summary: Thoughts on the nature of modern employer-employee relationships.  Some takeaways for me, much of it for managers.  Might have been better as a longform blog post.

author: Mark Manson
title: The Subtle Art of Not Giving a F*ck
summary: Didn't grab me much.  I'd rather read [Seneca][Letters from a Stoic] or [Marcus][Meditations] again.

author: John Steele Gordon
title: An Empire of Wealth
summary: A telling of the history of the United States through the lens of economics.  Role of central banks and markets.  Ability of the government to raise funds to wage war.  I really enjoyed this read.

author: Brad Stone
title: The Everything Store
summary: The story of Jeff Bezos and Amazon.  If you're at all interested in the expansion of Tech beyond purely digital pursuits, this book has many lessons.

author: B. H. Liddell Hart
title: Sherman: Soldier, Realist, American
summary: Biography of William Tecumseh Sherman, his life and his Civil War campaign that defined much of modern warfare.  I had no idea how bold the march to Savannah really was.

author: Chuck Yaeger
title: Yaeger: An Autobiography
summary: One of a number of military biographies I read this year.  The best US fighter pilot there was and first man to break the sound barrier.

author: Kai Bird & Martin Sherwin
title: American Prometheus
summary: The life of Robert Oppenheimer, Los Alamos and the development of the atomic bomb and his subsequent pursecution during the Red Scare.

author: Rob Goodman & Jimmy Soni
title: Rome's Last Citizen
summary: Biography of Marcus Cato the Younger, enemy of both Caesar and Pompey.  One of the few men to fight for the idea of the Republic to the very end against dictators to the very end, choosing suicide over submission.

author: Michael Lewis
title: Moneyball
summary: Someone uses data to overturn conventional wisdom and wins big.  Classic data scientist read.  Also useful for explaining what I do to regular people.

author: Walter Isaacson
title: Einstein: His Life and Universe
summary: Sadly, not as good as Franklin.  Not because Isaacson wrote a poor book, but Einstein's life wasn't particulary interesting after general relativity.

author: Oliver Burkeman
title: The Antidote: Happiness for People Who Can't Stand Positive Thinking
summary: I generally don't include subtitles here and I generally don't read much modern pop-philosophy.  This book is an exception.  It does a fantastic job of weaving many of my philosophical influences into one thread.

author: Carl Anderson
title: Creating a Data-Driven Organization
summary: Good conceptual framework for the steps required to make data and data science effective at a company.

author: Ryan Holiday
title: The Daily Stoic
summary: Daily Stoicism reader.  It's on my bedside table, but I haven't opened it as much as I think I should.

author: Steven Pressfield
title: The Warrior Ethos
summary: I'm a big fan of Pressfield's writing and the mentality of doing one's duty.  This book scratches both those itches.

author: Kevin Kelly
title: The Inevitable
summary: Founding editor of Wired discusses future trends in consumer Internet technology.  Kelly presents a fascinating view of the technological future, better framing things I had thought of and introducing many new ideas.  My main complaint is that it's an overly rosy picture that doesn't really consider societal impact of many of these changes.

author: Edward Slingerland
title: Trying Not to Try
summary: Ancient Chinese philosophy meets modern cognition.  Reframes the role of Kahneman's System 1 and System 2 in the constellation of Daoist with insights on how to make it applicable to your life.

author: Tyler Cowen
title: Average Is Over
summary: Followup to _The Great Stagnation_ detailing the ongoing bifurcation of American society into the haves and the have-nots.  Economic forces will progressively reduce the middle class that has dominated the 20th century.

author: Ryan Holiday
title: Ego Is the Enemy
summary: Another modern Stoicism book.  Holiday continues the Stoic tradition of distilling things to a series of life-hacks.  Love it, hate it, but if works, use it.

author: Steven Pressfield
title: The War of Art
summary: Modern-day Marcus Aurelius reminding you to show up and do your assigned work professionally, as difficult as it may be.

author: Oliver Sacks
title: On the Move
summary: Endearing autobiography.  I've always loved Sacks.  It was encouraging to read that someone I respect still felt he had no idea what he was doing at the age of 40.

author: Jean Edward Smith
title: Eisenhower in War and Peace
summary: I bought it for the perspective on the European theater, but was equally interested in his presidency.

author: Michael Lewis
title: Flash Boys
summary: The dark and dirty world of high-frequency trading.  This is absolutely nuts.

author: Tyler Cowen
title: The Great Stagnation
summary: We've run out of the major contributors to the last century of American growth.  The future will not continue at the same pace.

author: Mason Currey
title: [Daily Rituals: How Artists Work
summary: Delightful little book recounting the daily rituals and working habits of many artists.  A wonderful diversity of approaches.  My only regret is he didn't include more scientists and thinkers.

author: Daniel Kahneman
title: Thinking, Fast and Slow
summary: Summary of Kahnemann's research career into cognitive biases.  Got distracted after the first section.  While I think the book is right in broad strokes, I don't think we understand the brain well enough to consider the specifics gospel.

author: Nathaniel Philbrick
title: In the Heart of the Sea
summary: True story of the whaleship Essex.  Attacked by sperm whale in the Pacific, it was Melville's inspiration for Moby Dick.

author: John Vaillant
title: The Golden Spruce
summary: Man cuts down golden-needled tree on Haida Gwaii.  I mostly enjoyed it for the description of the British Columbian coastal wilderness.

author: Winifred Gallagher
title: Rapt: Attention and the Focused Life
summary: Author is diagnosed cancer, realizes her life is improved by living more in the present.  Sadly this book is mostly pop-psychology and doesn't introspect much how attention improved her life.

author: Pedro Domingos
title: The Master Algorithm
summary: Summary of the major approaches to machine learning that turns into an ad for the author's research.  A few insights.

author: Donald Barlett
title: Howard Hughes: His Life and Madness
summary: For as much as Hughes is a household name, I was surprised how little I knew about his life.  Hughes was a complete nut.
